source: Advanced Options Income Strategies - Synthesized Knowledge

chunks.content: The Wheel Strategy is a systematic income approach cycling between cash-secured puts and covered calls. PHASE 1 - SELLING PUTS: Identify stock you want to own at lower price. Sell OTM put (delta 0.20-0.30) at support level. Collect premium while waiting for better entry. If assigned: Great - you bought stock at discount (strike - premium). If not assigned: Keep premium, repeat. PHASE 2 - COVERED CALLS: Once assigned, sell OTM call above cost basis. Strike should be above (stock purchase price - all premiums collected). If called away: Profit locked in, return to Phase 1. If not called: Keep premium, sell another call. CYCLE CONTINUES: Keep wheeling the same stock, collecting premium in both phases. Best candidates: High-quality dividend stocks with moderate volatility, liquid options, stable businesses you'd hold long-term anyway.

Risk management for the Wheel: (1) STOCK SELECTION: Only wheel stocks you genuinely want to own. Never wheel a stock just because premium is high. (2) STRIKE SELECTION: Put strike at technical support. Call strike above cost basis. (3) POSITION SIZING: Max 5% of portfolio in single wheel position. (4) ROLLING DOWN: If stock drops significantly after assignment, can sell puts at lower strike to accumulate more shares at better price. (5) NEVER ROLL INDEFINITELY: If thesis is broken, exit position. Don't hold a falling knife. (6) DIVIDEND CONSIDERATION: Ex-dividend dates can trigger early assignment on calls - plan accordingly. (7) AVOID EARNINGS: Don't have short options open through earnings if you're income-focused. Common mistake: Wheeling high-IV stocks that are fundamentally weak. Premium is high for a reason - the stock is risky.

The Poor Man's Covered Call uses a LEAPS call instead of stock as the base position. Construction: Buy deep ITM LEAPS call (delta 0.70-0.80, 12+ months). Sell short-term OTM call (delta 0.20-0.30, 30-45 DTE). Benefits: (1) Much lower capital requirement than traditional covered call. (2) Defined risk (max loss = LEAPS cost - premium collected). (3) Similar profit profile to covered call. (4) Can be deployed on expensive stocks. Management: (1) Roll short call monthly for ongoing income. (2) Roll LEAPS when it has 90-120 days remaining. (3) Close entire position if stock drops significantly. Risks: (1) LEAPS time decay if held too long. (2) Wide bid-ask spreads on LEAPS. (3) Assignment on short call before LEAPS expiration. Best for: Capital-efficient covered call alternative on expensive stocks.

Iron condor management techniques: ENTRY: Sell 16-delta strangle, buy wings 5-10 points further out. Collect at least 1/3 width of wider spread. Target IV Rank > 50%. MANAGEMENT: (1) Take profit at 50% of max profit. (2) Close at 21 DTE regardless of P/L. (3) If one side tested (strike breached): Roll untested side closer to collect more credit. (4) If both sides threatened: Close position - wrong market read. ADJUSTMENT TECHNIQUES: (1) Roll up/down: Move entire spread to better centered position. (2) Add calendar: Buy back-month option to add vega and reduce delta. (3) Convert to broken wing butterfly: Shift strikes asymmetrically. (4) Close tested side, manage remaining side as credit spread. Key insight: Managing iron condors is more important than entry. Winners are made through good management, not perfect entries.

chunks.topic: Jade Lizard and Big Lizard Strategies
chunks.content: JADE LIZARD: Short put + short call spread (bear call spread). Construction: Sell OTM put. Sell OTM call. Buy further OTM call. Key: Total credit > call spread width = No upside risk! Profit zone: Between put strike and short call strike. Max loss: Put strike - Total credit (assignment risk only). Use when: Neutral to slightly bullish, want protection against upside blow-out. BIG LIZARD: Same as Jade Lizard but sell ATM call instead of OTM. Higher premium, more aggressive stance. Example Jade Lizard: Stock at $100. Sell $95 put for $1.50. Sell $105 call for $1.00. Buy $110 call for $0.40. Total credit = $2.10. Call spread width = $5. Since $2.10 < $5, there IS some upside risk ($5 - $2.10 = $2.90). To make 'riskless' upside: need tighter call spread or higher put premium.

A ratio backspread buys more options than it sells, profiting from large moves. CALL RATIO BACKSPREAD: Sell 1 ATM call. Buy 2 OTM calls. Often done for even money or small credit. Profit profile: Unlimited profit if stock surges. Small profit/loss if stock stays flat. Max loss at long strike at expiration. PUT RATIO BACKSPREAD: Sell 1 ATM put. Buy 2 OTM puts. Unlimited profit if stock crashes. Use cases: (1) Pre-earnings when expecting large move but unsure of direction. (2) Takeover speculation. (3) FDA binary events. (4) Cheap lottery tickets with limited downside. Key advantage: Define your max loss (at the long strike), but have unlimited potential. Better risk/reward than long straddles in some cases. Timing: Best entered when IV is low - you're net long vega.

A double diagonal combines two diagonal spreads (put side and call side). Construction: Buy longer-term OTM put. Sell shorter-term further OTM put. Buy longer-term OTM call. Sell shorter-term further OTM call. Creates a strangle-like position with calendar-like characteristics. Benefits: (1) Profits from time decay (short options decay faster). (2) Profits from IV increase (long options have more vega). (3) Wide profit zone. (4) Defined risk. (5) Good for high-IV environments expecting volatility to persist. Management: Roll short options monthly for ongoing income. Keep long options as base until 60-90 DTE remaining, then roll them out. Risk: Large quick move can hurt position before time decay kicks in. Best for: Range-bound markets with elevated IV, patient traders.

The Super Bull is a leveraged bullish strategy combining bull call spread with short put. Construction: Buy ATM call. Sell OTM call. Sell cash-secured put (same strike as long call or lower). Result: Bull call spread funded by short put premium. Often can be entered for zero cost or credit. Profit profile: Profit from moderate rise (like bull spread). Profit if stock stays flat (from put premium). Risk: Assigned on put if stock falls significantly. Max profit: Same as bull call spread width. Example: Stock at $100. Buy $100 call for $5. Sell $110 call for $2. Net debit = $3. Sell $95 put for $3. Now zero cost! Max profit = $10 (spread width) if stock at $110+. Max risk = $95 - $0 = $95 (put assignment). Best for: High conviction bullish plays where you'd buy stock anyway.

A skip-strike butterfly has asymmetric wings, creating directional bias. Construction (Bullish Skip-Strike): Buy 1 ITM call. Sell 2 ATM calls. Buy 1 OTM call (but skip one strike - further OTM than standard butterfly). Difference from regular butterfly: Wider profit zone on one side. Slightly higher cost. More room for directional move. Use when: (1) Expecting pinning action but with directional bias. (2) Want wider profit zone than standard butterfly. (3) Playing support/resistance levels with room for upside. Variations: Can skip strikes on either side depending on directional bias. Skip-strike on upside = bullish. Skip-strike on downside = bearish. Advanced technique for experienced butterfly traders.

Gamma scalping profits from realized volatility exceeding implied volatility. Setup: Buy straddle or strangle (long gamma position). Delta hedge continuously as underlying moves. How it works: (1) Enter long straddle (long gamma, long vega). (2) As stock moves up, delta becomes positive - sell stock to delta-hedge. (3) As stock moves down, delta becomes negative - buy stock to delta-hedge. (4) Each round trip captures profit if move is larger than theta decay. Profit condition: Realized volatility > Implied volatility. Loss condition: Stock stays flat (theta decay kills position). Frequency: Can hedge hourly, daily, or at price thresholds. Best for: High-frequency traders in volatile markets. Requires significant capital and attention. Not suitable for retail traders without automation.

Trading volatility directly through VIX products. VIX Cash: The index itself - cannot be traded directly. VIX Futures: Trade expectations of future VIX levels. Usually in contango (futures > spot). VIX Options: Options on VIX futures, not VIX cash. Strategies: (1) SELL VIX PUTS: When VIX spikes, sell puts to collect premium from mean reversion. (2) VIX CALL SPREADS: Cheap hedge against market crashes (VIX spikes when market falls). (3) VXX COVERED CALLS: Own VXX, sell calls - captures contango decay. (4) CALENDAR SPREADS: Exploit VIX futures term structure. Risk warning: VIX products are complex and can move dramatically. VXX decays over time due to contango. UVXY/SVXY have leverage and can move 50%+ in a day. Only for experienced volatility traders.

RISK REVERSAL: Bullish synthetic using options. Sell OTM put, buy OTM call (same expiration). Zero cost if structured correctly. Profit: Unlimited upside above call strike. Risk: Own stock at put strike if it falls. Use: Express bullish view without buying stock upfront. COLLAR: Protective strategy for existing stock position. Own stock, buy OTM put (protection), sell OTM call (funds put). Zero cost if call premium = put premium. Profit: Capped at call strike. Protection: Losses limited below put strike. Use: Lock in gains while staying invested. Key difference: Risk reversal is a way to GET long. Collar is a way to PROTECT long position. Both have similar structure (short put + long call) but different starting points and goals.

Synthetics replicate stock or option positions using other instruments. SYNTHETIC LONG STOCK: Buy ATM call + Sell ATM put = Same P/L as owning 100 shares. Less capital than buying stock outright. SYNTHETIC SHORT STOCK: Sell ATM call + Buy ATM put = Same P/L as shorting 100 shares. No borrowing required. SYNTHETIC LONG CALL: Buy stock + Buy put = Same P/L as long call (married put). SYNTHETIC LONG PUT: Short stock + Buy call = Same P/L as long put. SYNTHETIC SHORT CALL: Short stock + Sell put = Same P/L as short call. SYNTHETIC SHORT PUT: Buy stock + Sell call = Covered call = Same P/L as short put. Applications: (1) Avoid short sale restrictions. (2) Capital efficiency. (3) Arbitrage mispricings. (4) Understand put-call parity. Put-Call Parity: Call - Put = Stock - Strike * e^(-rT). Synthetics exploit this relationship.

A box spread locks in risk-free profit through put-call parity arbitrage. Construction: Buy bull call spread (buy lower strike call, sell higher strike call). Buy bear put spread (buy higher strike put, sell lower strike put). All same expiration. Result: Guaranteed payoff = Strike difference at expiration. Example: $100/$110 box. Always worth exactly $10 at expiration (minus interest). Arbitrage: If box can be bought for < $10 PV, or sold for > $10 PV, there's arbitrage. Reality check: (1) Arbitrage opportunities are rare and small. (2) Transaction costs often eliminate profit. (3) Early assignment risk with American options. (4) Mainly used by market makers and institutions. Retail use: Occasionally used for tax strategies or synthetic lending. Not a trading strategy for profit - more of a structural tool.
